Jim O'Flaherty


--- John Arrowwood <jarrowwx@...> wrote:

> I wanted to throw out the other alternative that I myself implemented.  
> 
> Based on what Ken described, a 5 layer network will require being
> activated in 5 discreet time steps.  But if there is no recurrency,
> then it should be possible to activate it in ONE time step by just
> activating each of the nodes in the proper order.  That's what I did. 
> For a given topology, I do a dependency analysis.  From that, I figure
> out what the proper order should be in order to activate individual
> nodes.  If I activate the nodes in that order, then the inputs will
> reach the outputs in a single activation of the network.  This, in
> turn, reduces the number of calculations required for an activation.
> 
> For recurrent networks, you can do it in much the same way.  However,
> if node A has an input coming from node B, but node B hasn't been
> calculated, you use an assumed output of 0 for node B.  On the next
> activation of the network, node B *has* been calculated.  Let's say
> it's output was X.  So A will use X as the value of the input from B.
> 
> Mind you, if you use this technique, you will save a great deal on CPU
> resources, since you don't have to do nearly as many calculations. 
> However, you can't (necessarily) mix the paradigms.  You can't develop
> a topology using Ken's activation technique and expect it to perform
> identically using mine, and vice versa.  It might, but it might not! 
> So whatever you decide on, stick with it.
> 
> Realistically, how you do it isn't that important.  The network will
> learn (or evolve) to solve the problem using whatever method you
> decide upon.  The only advantage of one method over another is in how
> much computational resources are required either during testing or in
> final implementation.  My NEAT was written in Perl, which is an
> interpreted language, and so could benefit from as much accelleration
> as I could find.  That's why I opted for the less computationally
> intensive activation method.  If you don't care about CPU resources
> during the firing of the network, then go with whatever is easiest for
> you to code.  :)
> 
> -- John
> 
> On 8/24/05, Kenneth Stanley <kstanley@...> wrote:
> > Kevin,
> > 
> > Let me add to Charles comments a bit...although Charles does a good
> > job giving some background, I believe there are some things Charles
> > didn't mention you should be aware of.
> > 
> > First, see the question, "How are networks with arbitrary topologies
> > activated?" in the NEAT FAQ located at:
> > 
> > http://www.cs.utexas.edu/users/kstanley/neat.html
> > 
> > That question gives some background on your own question.
> > 
> > The short answer is that every node is activated on every timestep
> > from ALL incoming connections.  Any node that has not yet received
> > input it assumed to be outputting a zero.  In other words, time
> > delay does not enter into it at all (I have never actually used the
> > time-delay code).  Also, activation does not travel all the way from
> > inputs to outputs in a single timestep unless there is a direct
> > connection from inputs to outputs.  But activation traveling over
> > intervening nodes will take extra time to get there.
> > 
> > So what happens is that a node that connects to itself receives the
> > activation that itself output on the *previous* timestep.  Networks
> > are activated over a series of timesteps.
> > 
> > It is important to note that you should *not* be relaxing a network
> > during a control task like food gathering.  Charles mentions
> > relaxation but that is only appropriate for classification tasks
> > where the network is trying to decide on a final answer.  See the
> > question, "How do I ensure that a network stabilizes before taking
> > its output(s) for a classification problem?" in the NEAT FAQ for
> > more info on this.
> > 
> > In a continual control task like food gathering (or most tasks NEAT
> > is used for) there is always new input coming in and new output
> > coming out, so the network will never relax, since there is
> > no "final" answer.  The only question that comes up is how many
> > times (steps) to activate the network per world tick.  Almost any
> > experiment I've heard of activates once per tick, but it is possible
> > to imagine activating >1 time per tick, which is equivalent to
> > speeding up the rate of thought.   However, note that more
> > activations also means more CPU time per world tick.
> > 
> > I hope this help; feel free to ask any other questions.
> > 
> > ken
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > 
> > --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Charles Tarun <ctarun@g...> wrote:
> > > Hello Maitrikaruna,
> > > I would like to offer any help I can, and I'm sure others will
> > also help,
> > >
> > > I also don't have any training on NN either, but I've been read a
> > lot about
> > > them. Each implementation of NEAT handles the firing of the node
> > in their
> > > own way, as NEAT doesn't define it exactly. My method of choice is
> > one of
> > > the SharpNEAT ones, "FastConcurrentNetwork". This network
> > simulates each
> > > neuron activating concurrently.
> > >
> > > 1) Assign the values to all input nodes
> > > 2) Activate the network
> > > 3) Relax the network
> > > 4) Read the outputs
> > >
> > > Activate network is pass a parameter of how many times to run for,
> > this is
> > > basically how many steps to run for. Each step uses the signal
> > strength from
> > > the previous.
> > >
> > > The Relax network function is very much like the Activate
> > function, but also
> > > take in a maxAllowedSignalDelta. It runs until the signal change
> > for each
> > > node is <maxAllowedSignalDelta or the maxSteps count is reached.
> > >
> > > |-------
> > > v |
> > > NODE1-->NODE2-->NODE3
> > >
> > > They way I see this working with your diagram is(assuming the
> > links had
> > > enough weight to cause the next to fire):
> > >
> > > Step 1:
> > > Node1(input) is firing.
> > > node2 get enough signal to fire at this time stamp
> > > node3 only getting signal from the previous step when node2 wasn't
> > firing
> > > does not have enough signal to fire.
> > >
> > > Step2:
> > > Node1(input) is firing.
> > > node2 gets enough signal to fire from node1's last step, but is
> > not getting
> > > signal from node3.
> > > node3 gets enough signal to fire from node2's last step and fires
> > >
> > > step3:
> > > Node1(input) is firing(As always, input nodes don't change)
> > > node2 is getting signal from node1 and node3 now
> > > node3 is getting signal from node2 last time step, the recurrent
> > connection
> > > hasn't effected the signal from 2 to 3 yet.
> > >
> > > Under such a system it is possible to get oscillation in the
> > signals, that's
> > > why there is a maxSteps on the relax function. The creator of
> > SharpNEAT is
> > > part of this list as well(Colin D. Green). I hope this will be
> > helpful.
> > >
> > > Chuck Tarun
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > >
> > > On 8/24/05, maitrikaruna <kevin@t...> wrote:
> > > >
> > > > Hello all,
> > > >
> > > > I stumbled on NEAT just a short week ago and have found it very
> > > > interesting. I spent the last few days implementing NEAT in
> > > > PowerBASIC and I'm nearly done. I am doing a rather simple
> > > > simulation.
> > > >
> > > > I basically set up a "room" and drop an agent in the middle.
> > > > The
> > > > agent needs to eatï¿½so I place a large circle representing
> > food in
> > > > the
> > > > room. The agent has so many steps to find the food or it
> > > > disappears. The food is then moved to a new location and the
> > agent
> > > > can try again. The agent is tested against four different food
> > > > locations. The agent has 8 sensors that allow it to "see" in
> > > > those 8
> > > > directions.
> > > >
> > > > Right now with only 50 parents and 10 generations it is able to
> > find
> > > > all the 4 different food bins after about9 or 10 gens...which is
> > > > pretty good.. Especially since I discovered that I have a neuron
> > > > firing issue in my code..
> > > >
> > > > Anyway..I am completely new to NN's...i have no training on them
> > at
> > > > all, although I do know GA's fairly well (I am CEO of
> > bioinformatics
> > > > firm that uses GA's to analyze genetics data).
> > > >
> > > > I have a question I hope you can help with. the way I setup the
> > > > networks allows for recurrent connections to occur. So suppose
> > you
> > > > have a simple netowrk where input node 1 connects to hidden node
> > 2,
> > > > which connects to hidden node 3, which connects to back to node
> > 2.
> > > > How is firing to proceed in such a scenario? Node 2 can't fire
> > > > until it has all its inputs, yet one of its outputs(the one to
> > node
> > > > 3) affects what its input will be. Thanks for your help...
> > > > |-------
> > > > v |
> > > > NODE1-->NODE2-->NODE3
> > > >
> > > > And what if a node links back to itself? Then how is the firing
> > > > sequence to work? I saw a time delay in teh C code and I am
> > > > guessing this is involved, but I'm not quite sure how...
> > > >
> > > > When I get this working, I would like to tackle the tic-tac-toe
> > > > problem you guys are working on.
> > > >
> > > > i really appreciate all your posts...very enlightening...
> > > >
> > > > Best,
> > > > Kevin Cramer
